choices.A: The path R1-R4-R5-R3 continues to be the best path because the metric is better.
choices.C: The path R1-R4-R5-R3 continues to be the best path because OSPF does not compare the metrics between two domains.
choices.D: The path reverts to R1-R2-R3 because this was the previous best path.
choices.B: The path reverts back to R1-R2-R3 because the route type is E1.

Refer to the exhibit. The network 10.10.0.0/16 has been redistributed to OSPF processes and the best path to the destination from R1 has been chosen as R1-R2-R3. A failure occurred on the link between R2 and R3, and the path was changed to R1-R4-R5-R3 What happens when the link between R2 and R3 is restored?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
OSPF path selection:
Intra-Area (O)
Inter-Area (O IA)
External Type 1 (E1)
External Type 2 (E2)
NSSA Type 1 (N1)
NSSA Type 2 (N2)

even if metric is higher on E1, it would still be selected over the E2 route

Selected Answer: B
B. I change my mind after more research. when an identical external route received from two OSPF instances on a router, the tie-breaker is the External Type (E1 vs E2). If they both were the same then it would be the OSPF instance ID. The outcome would be the same but the reason R1-R2-R3 path is preferred would be different.

Selected Answer: C
C. the router compares possible paths for a route only within each OSPF process (domain). So both OSPF processes have only one possible path for the route. However, only one path can be installed to the forwarding table at a time, even they have the same Administrative Distance.

Selected Answer: B
I think ans is B.

In OSPF, E1-type routes take into account not only the external cost but also the internal cost in the route metric; when the link between R2 and R3 is restored, the R1-R2-R3 path is again chosen as the best path because it has a lower metric including the internal cost

Selected Answer: D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/open-shortest-path-first-ospf/4170-ospfprocesses.html states
"The OSPF route selection rule is that intra-area routes are preferred over inter-area routes, which are preferred over external routes. However, this rule can apply to routes learned via the same process. In other words, there is no preference between external routes from one process compared to internal routes of other process."
It is implementation dependent which criteria is selected when two OSPF routes with same AD need to be compared, so it reverts back as the same rule (be it lowest router ID or whatever) is again selected as tie-braker.
Metric type/metric does not play a role here.

Selected Answer: B
E1 includes – the internal cost to ASBR added to the external cost, 
E2 does not include – internal cost. it is same as external cost. 

Cost ospf1 : 10 + 10 +100 = 120 
Cost ospf2 : 100

If both were the same type, R4-R5-R3 would be chosen based on cost. However, E1 is chosen before E2, even if E2 has a better metric

Selected Answer: C
obviously B or D. I vote B, because strictly speaking it doesn't matter which route was the best in the past. When the link comes back a new route calculation happens and R1-R2-R3 wins because of the metric, not for historical reasons.

Selected Answer: D
D is right. E1 is always chooses before E2 even with worst metric
